newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains cattle market not well tested-feedlots.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains cattle market not well tested-feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle markets near midday Tuesday were slow and not well tested, according to feedlot sources.

One load of heifers traded at $69.00 per cwt for cattle that had reportedly been on feed a little longer than usual, the sources said. However, details were not available regarding the quality of the heifers.
Top-quality cattle were bid $69.00 against asking levels of $71.00 to $72.00, they said.
Pricing attitudes were bolstered by ongoing light supplies of market-ready cattle, with many on showlists unfinished.
Feedlot cattle prices also were seen supported by moderate beef demand as retailers continued to place beef orders to be shipped in time for early November features, sources said.
At midday, beef prices were uneven, but stabilizing and movement was moderate, sources said.
Boxed beef was quoted up $0.18 per cwt to down $0.34, with 161 fabricated loads sold, according to USDA. Choice heavyweight cuts were down $0.34 at $104.93.
